poem:
**The Museum of What Once Was**

In a quiet hall, the echoes speak,  
of histories filed and shelves made neat.  
Dioramas stripped to bones,  
banished voices, unturned stones.  
Yet shadows linger, whispering past,  
no forceful pen can bind them fast.  
Truth drifts in corners unremarked,  
alive in the spaces borders marked.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why Trump’s attack on the Smithsonian matters | Kimberlé Crenshaw and Jason Stanley In a letter sent to Smithsonian secretary, Lonnie G Bunch III, on 12 August, the Trump administration announced its plan to replace all Smithsonian exhibits deemed as “divisive” or “ideological” with descriptions deemed as “historical” and “constructive”. On 21 August, just nine days later, the White House published a list of said offending fixtures – the majority of which include exhibits, programming". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Why Trump’s attack on the Smithsonian matters | Kimberlé Crenshaw and Jason Stanley In a letter sent to Smithsonian secretary, Lonnie G Bunch III, on 12 August, the Trump administration announced its plan to replace all Smithsonian exhibits deemed as “divisive” or “ideological” with descriptions deemed as “historical” and “constructive”. On 21 August, just nine days later, the White House published a list of said offending fixtures – the majority of which include exhibits, programming
